content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: Careless Whisper: Speech-to-Text Hallucination Harms
Link, Aberdeen Roll Out Dual Streaming Translation, Captioning
entries.snippet:
Link Electronics has partnered with Aberdeen Broadcast Services to introduce a real-time, dual-stream translation and captioning solution designed for broadcast and live audiences. The system utilizes advanced Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), Automated Machine Translation (AMT), and AI to deliver over 98% contextual accuracy in multiple languages. The process involves transmitting a broadcast audio stream through a Link Orion caption encoder via SDI, then routing the audio to Aberdeen's ASR cloud server using an IP connection. The server processes the audio for accurate, context-aware captions and translations and returns the data to the Orion encoder, which embeds it into the broadcast stream with both open and closed captioning options.

This cloud-based service also enables real-time distribution of captions and translations to personal devices for audience members, featuring synchronized playback and AI-generated voice dubs with selectable gender and tone. The dual-stream capability ensures both primary and secondary language outputs can be embedded on different caption channels, offering an efficient and cost-effective multilingual broadcast solution. More information is available on Link Electronics' website.

v.title: Sink or SWIM: Tackling Real-Time ASR at Scale
MuAViC: A Multilingual Audio-Visual Corpus for Robust Speech Recognition and Robust Speech-to-Text Translation
GigaSpeech: An Evolving, Multi-domain ASR Corpus with 10,000 Hours of Transcribed Audio

entries.title: Researchers say an AI-powered transcription tool used in hospitals invents things no one ever said
entries.snippet:
A growing concern is emerging over OpenAI's AI-powered transcription tool, Whisper, which is being used widely across industries including healthcare. Despite being praised for near-human level accuracy, experts have found that Whisper frequently introduces false or fabricated text, known as "hallucinations." These hallucinations can include imagined treatments, racial references, and violent statements‚Äîeven in clear, short audio clips. Researchers have found hallucinations in up to 80% of transcripts studied, raising alarm about its use in sensitive fields like medicine.

Whisper is already integrated into systems run by companies like Microsoft and Oracle and is used by over 30,000 clinicians through a Whisper-based medical tool developed by Nabla. Critics, including former OpenAI employees and academic researchers, warn that these errors can be dangerous in high-risk domains such as healthcare, especially since some hospitals erase original audio, removing a reference point for verification. OpenAI acknowledges the flaw and says it is working on improvements but advises against using Whisper in critical decision-making contexts. Lawmakers and patient advocates express additional concern over privacy issues tied to the use of sensitive audio by large tech platforms.

entries.title: Best transcription service of 2025
entries.snippet:
The article from TechRadar outlines the best transcription services of 2025, evaluating each based on factors such as accuracy, speed, pricing, and specialized capabilities. It emphasizes that while basic speech-to-text tools are available, they often fall short in technical fields such as legal or medical transcription, where professional services are preferred.

Top picks include:

- **Transcription Panda**: Best overall for non-urgent needs, offering affordable pricing and up to five-day turnaround.
- **TranscribeMe**: Recognized for affordability and quality, making it suitable for budget-conscious users.
- **GoTranscript**: Excels in fast turnaround and handles complex or technical content well.
- **GMR Transcription**: Offers diverse services including Spanish and text-to-text transcription, though it's pricier and slower unless expedited.
- **Rev**: Best for audio/video transcription with high accuracy and additional services like captions and subtitles.
- **Temi**: Automated and fast, ideal for users needing high-speed service with fair accuracy.
- **Scribie**: Known for its premium accuracy and variable plans, offering both manual and automated options.

The article concludes that selection depends on user priorities‚Äîspeed, cost, or accuracy‚Äîand advises careful consideration of needs for optimal service choice.

entries.title: Transcribing Audio Sucks-So Make the Machines Do It
entries.snippet:
Trint is a web-based transcription tool launched in late 2016 that uses advanced voice-recognition technology to convert audio and video recordings into searchable, editable text. Unlike other services that rely on humans to refine transcripts, Trint is entirely machine-based, offering transcription at a significantly lower cost (about 25 cents per minute). It includes a browser-based editor that links words to the exact point in the recording, aiding fast corrections and usability. Though not perfectly accurate‚Äîespecially in noisy settings or with overlapping voices‚Äîit performs well with clean audio, boasting an error rate of 5‚Äì10%. Trint currently understands 13 languages and continues to improve via frequent updates.

The tool has practical applications for journalists, filmmakers, researchers, and podcasters, unlocking previously hard-to-index media for better search and accessibility. Despite some limitations with heavily accented or fast speech, Trint is considered a state-of-the-art system for its purpose. Future developments include speaker identification (diarization) and expanded use in media archiving and event transcription. Its biggest competitive advantage lies in its unique combination of transcription accuracy and time-coded editorial interface, making it a potential game-changer in voice-to-text automation.

v.title: OpenAI's Transcription Tool Hallucinates. Hospitals Are Using It Anyway
v.snippet:
An investigation by the Associated Press has revealed significant issues with OpenAI‚Äôs Whisper transcription tool, particularly in medical and business contexts. Whisper, which was released in 2022 and claimed to approach human-level accuracy, has been shown to fabricate or "hallucinate" text that was never spoken. Researchers and developers have discovered invented content in a large number of test transcripts‚Äîup to 80% in one study.

Despite OpenAI's warnings against using Whisper for ‚Äúhigh-risk domains,‚Äù over 30,000 medical workers across 40 health systems, including Mankato Clinic and Children's Hospital Los Angeles, use Whisper-powered tools by Nabla, which deletes original audio for data safety, further complicating the reliability of transcripts.

Beyond healthcare, Whisper has been found to insert nonexistent and harmful content into audio transcriptions, including racial and violent statements, due to biases in its training data and its predictive nature. This behavior is attributed to the model‚Äôs reliance on web-based, captioned audio content likely sourced from YouTube.

Experts warn that Whisper‚Äôs use in critical domains could lead to serious consequences, urging stronger regulation and validation of AI tools to prevent harm from inaccurate AI-generated information.
